title: Preparation of Naringenin Solution for In Vivo Application
procedures:
The investigations described conformed to the Guidelines for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals of the National Research Council and were approved by the Shanghai University of Traditional Chinese Medicine Animal Care and Use Committee. When performing the experiments, lab coats, disposable nitrile gloves, and goggles are required for safety purposes.
1. Preparation of solvents and estimation of naringenin required for in vivo application
Prepare the following solvents: Tween-80 (final concentration range: 0.5%-1%), DMSO, glycerin (final concentration range: 15%-20%), ethanol (final concentration range: 12% for intramuscular injection)22, and 0.9% PS.
Estimate the amount of naringenin required based on the dose, number of mice, and injection frequency.
	
Order 10 mice (C57BL/6, male, 5 weeks old, SPF) to administer naringenin 5 days a week for 8 weeks. Keep mice in specific pathogen-free (SPF) conditions.
		NOTE: The dose required for intraperitoneal injection is 20 mg/kg b.w.23.
Weigh 160 mg of naringenin based on the following calculation: 20 mg/kg x 0.02 kg/mouse x 10 mice x 5 days/week x 8 weeks = 160 mg.
Calculate the concentration of naringenin to be injected in vivo.
	
Prepare the recommended volume based on the bodyweight of the mice. The recommended volume of naringenin applied to each mouse is 1% of body weight (0.3 mL). In this experiment, 0.2 mL per mouse was used.
Calculate the total volume: 0.2 mL per mouse x 10 mice x 5 days/week x 8 weeks = 80 mL.
Calculate the concentration of the Naringenin in stock: 160 mg/80 mL solvents = 2 mg/mL.
Calculate the volume for each day: 0.2 mL per mouse x 10 mice = 2 mL.
2. Dissolution
Ethanol solution
	
To prepare naringenin solution at 2 mg/mL, weigh 3.52 mg of naringenin and add it into a 2.0 mL tube.

NOTE: To achieve a concentration of 2 mg/mL, the total volume required will be 1760 µL (calculation: 3.52 mg/1760 µL = 2 mg/mL).
Quickly spin down (2000 x g for 30 s) to make the naringenin powder settle at the bottom of the tube (Figure 1A).
Add 8.8 µL of 100% ethanol to the tube to prepare a 0.5% (v/v) solution with respect to the total volume required2. Naringenin does not dissolve completely (Figure 1B).
Continue to add 79.2 µL of 100% ethanol to the tube to prepare a 5% (v/v) solution with respect to the total volume required (calculation: (79.2 µL + 8.8 µL) / 1760 µL x 100% = 5%). Naringenin does not dissolve completely (Figure 1B).
Add 1672 µL of 0.9% PS to the tube containing 5% ethanol as described in step 2.1.4. This will produce an emulsion (Figure 1D). Centrifuge (2000 x g for 30 s) the solution to check whether naringenin is completely dissolved in the solution. White precipitates of undissolved naringenin appear in the solution (Figure 1E).
DMSO solution
	
To prepare naringenin solution at 2 mg/mL, weigh 3.95 mg of naringenin and add into a 2.0 mL tube.
		​NOTE: To achieve a concentration of 2 mg/mL, the total volume required will be 1975 µL (calculation: 3.95 mg/1975 µL = 2 mg/mL).
Quickly spin down (2000 x g for 30 s) to make the naringenin powder settle at the bottom of the tube.
Add 9.8 µL of DMSO to the tube to prepare a 0.5% (v/v) solution (calculation: 9.8 µL/1975 µL x 100% = 5%). Naringenin dissolves completely (Figure 2A).

Add 88.2 µL of DMSO to the tube to prepare a 5% (v/v) solution with respect to the total volume required (calculation: (88.2 µL + 9.8 µL) /1975 µL x 100% = 5%). Naringenin dissolves completely (Figure 2B).
Add 1877 µL of 0.9% PS (v/v percent of 95%) to the solution prepared in step 2.2.4. An emulsion is produced (Figure 1C). Centrifuge (2000 x g for 30 s) the solution to check whether naringenin is completely dissolved in the solution. White precipitates of undissolved naringenin appear in the solution (Figure 1D).
Tween-80 and DMSO solution
	
To prepare the naringenin solution at 2 mg/mL, weigh 6.69 mg of naringenin and add into a 5.0 mL tube.
		​NOTE: To achieve the final concentration of 2 mg/mL, the total solution volume required will be 3345 µL (calculation: 6.69 mg/3345 µL = 2 mg/mL).
Quickly spin down (2000 x g for 30 s) to make the naringenin powder settle at the bottom of the tube.
Add 117.7 µL of DMSO to prepare a 3.5% (v/v) solution with respect to the total volume required (calculation: 117.7 µL /3345 µL x 100% = 3.5%). Naringenin dissolves completely (Figure 3A)
Add 117.7 µL of Tween 80 to the solution prepared in step 2.3.3 to attain 3.5% (v/v) Tween 80 and 3.5% (v/v) DMSO. Observe the complete dissolution of naringenin (Figure 3B)
Slowly add the solution prepared in step 2.3.4 to a 5.0 mL tube containing 3109.6 µL of 0.9% PS (v/v percent of 93%) and shake well to obtain an apparent naringenin solution (Figure 3C).
Let the solution prepared in step 2.3.5 stay at room temperature (RT) for 2 h. The solution is still apparent without any visible precipitates (Figure 3D).
Preparation of naringenin solution for in vivo administration

According to step 1.2.2, weigh 160 mg of naringenin (160 mg / 2 mg/mL = 80 mL).
Add 2.8 mL of DMSO to attain 3.5% (v/v) solution (calculation: 2.8 mL / 80 mL x 100% = 3.5%)
Then, add 2.8 mL of Tween 80 to the solution prepared in step 2.4.2 to attain 3.5% (v/v) Tween 80 and 3.5% (v/v) DMSO.
Aliquot the solution prepared in step 2.4.3 into four tubes, 1.4 mL per tube [(2.8 mL + 2.8 mL) / 4 = 1.4 mL].
Aliquot 18.6 mL of 0.9% PS to five 15 mL tubes.
Store the solution prepared in step 2.4.3 (stock solution) and 2.4.5 at 4 °C (2.8 mL + 2.8 mL + 18.6 mL x 4 = 80 mL).
Take 140 µL of the stock solution (step 2.4.3) and mix it with 1860 µL of 0.9% PS to prepare 2 mL of naringenin solution for 1 day of administeration.
Filter the solution through a 0.2 µm filter.
3. Naringenin solution administration
Handling and restraint
	
Spray the cage and hands with 70-75% alcohol before opening the lid. Lift the mouse by the base of the tail and place it on a solid surface to position its tail gently back.
Grasp the scruff of the neck behind the ears with the left thumb and index finger and position the tail between the little and the ring finger. Keep the mouse in a supine position with its posterior end slightly elevated.
Injection
	
Grasp the back skin of the mouse so that the abdominal skin is taut.
Push the needle (insulin syringe) in at an angle of 10° between the needle and the abdominal surface, in the lower right or left quadrant of the abdomen to avoid hitting the bladder, liver, or other internal organs.

Run the needle subcutaneously in a cranial direction for 3-5 mm, and then insert it at a 45° angle into the abdominal cavity.
When the needle passes through the abdominal wall and the resistance disappears, perform an aspiration to confirm that no reflux material is withdrawn. Then, slowly push the solution.
After the injection, slowly pull the needle out and rotate it slightly to prevent leakage. The recommended volume is 50-100 µL/10 g.
Dispose of leftover Naringenin in a biohazard container.
4. Blood glucose test
NOTE: Test the blood glucose 1 day prior to the injection and 1 and 2 months after the injection.
Fast the mice for 15 h before the blood glucose test. Water can continue to be provided.
Open the test strips and mark the date. Once opened, use the test strips within 3 months. Store the test strips at 2-30 °C. Tightly close the lid after removing the strip to prevent the formation of moisture.
Place the animal into the induction chamber. Turn on the vaporizer at an induction level of 4% for isoflurane and 4 L/min for oxygen. After the animal is fully anesthetized, maintain the anesthetic with the nose cone and the anesthetic delivery at a level of 1.5% for isoflurane and 0.4 L/min for oxygen.
Wipe the tail with cotton balls/swabs soaked in 70%-75% alcohol.
Starting from the lowest point of the tail, make a small puncture on the lateral tail vein with a 25G needle prick and squeeze out a drop of blood.
Wipe the drop of blood with a tissue paper.
Squeeze out another drop of blood and collect it on the edge of a test strip.
Read and record the result displayed on the glucose meter.

To stop the bleeding, pinch the tail of the mouse with a sterile gauze and wipe the area with 75% alcohol.
Additional samples may be obtained by a similar technique moving up the tail cranially.
5. TRAP staining
Slides preparation
	
Perform fasting blood glucose tests on the mice once a week. When the blood glucose levels are ≥ 11.1 mmol/L (indicative of successful type II diabetes mice model24), euthanize the mice using CO2, followed by cervical disclocation, and collect the Lumbar 4th-6th (L4-L6) (no euthanasia is performed while fasting blood glucose test).
Fix the L4-L6 samples with 4% paraformaldehyde for 24 h (ensure that the volume of paraformaldehyde is >20x the volume of the tissue), and then wash for 2 h in continuous flow of tap water.
To decalcify the samples, immerse them in a 10% ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) solution for 2 weeks at RT in static condition until the samples are softened. Ensure that the volume of the decalcifying solution is 20-30 times the volume of the tissue/sample. Change the EDTA solution every other day.
Dehydrate the sample using a dehydrator.
		
Place the specimens in tissue processing embedding cassettes. Number the cassette using a pencil.
Set the dehydrator program as follows: 75% alcohol for 2 h, 85% alcohol for 1 h, 95% alcohol for 1 h, 95% alcohol for 2 h, anhydrous ethanol (I) for 2 h, anhydrous ethanol (II) for 2 h, anhydrous ethanol (III) for 2 h, xylene (I) for 1 h, xylene (II) for 1 h, xylene (III) for 1 h, paraffin wax (I) for 2 h, and paraffin wax (II) for 2 h, at RT.
Embed the samples in paraffin wax.

Add paraffin wax to the cassette tray of the paraffin embedding station and heat to 60 °C. Immerse the dehydrated specimens for at least 2 h.
Place the tissue cassette in the cassette tray and preheat.
Add paraffin wax to the paraffin reservoir and heat to 60 °C.
After 2 h, take both tissue cassette and specimens to the work area. Pour the preheated paraffin wax from the paraffin reservoir into the tissue cassette. Place the specimen into the paraffin wax, ensure that the paraffin wax completely covers the tissue, and then immediately move the cassette onto an icing station.
Use a microtome to cut the paraffin-embedded samples into 5-6 µm sections. Unfold the sections in 40 °C warm water for less than 10 s. Collect the sections on APS (amino silane) coated glass slides. Dry the slides at RT for 1 h, and then move the slides into an oven set at 60 °C for overnight.
TRAP reagent preparation
	
Prepare basic stock incubation solution: Dissolve 9.2 g of sodium acetate anhydrous, 11.4 g of L-(+) tartaric acid, and 2.8 mL of glacial acid in 1000 mL of distilled water. Adjust pH to 4.7-5.0 and store at RT for up to 6 months.
Prepare Naphthol-ether solution: Dissolve 0.1 g of naphthol AS-BI phosphate in 5 mL of ethylene glycol monoethyl ether. Store at 4 °C for up to 5 weeks.
Prepare Sodium nitrite solution: Dissolve 1 g of sodium nitrite in 25 mL of distilled water. Store at 4 °C.
Prepare Pararosaniline dye: Add 1 g of pararosaniline base to 20 mL of 2N HCl (83 mL of HCl in 417 mL of water). Use a stir plate to dissolve the base and filter it before use.
TRAP staining

Fill two Coplin jars with 50 mL of basic stock incubation solution and place in a 37 °C oven for 2 h.
Take one Coplin jar and add 0.5 mL of naptol-ether solution.
Place the slides in the Coplin jar and incubate at 37 °C for 1 h.
		NOTE: Prepare atleast three slides for each group.
A few minutes before the incubation time is over, add 1 mL of sodium nitrite solution and 1 mL of pararosaniline dye. Mix gently for 30 s and leave it for 2 min.
Add the solution prepared in step 5.2.2 to the other preheated Coplin jar containing the basic stock solution. Mix the solution well and insert the slides from the Coplin jar in step 5.3.3.
Incubate for 15-20 min at RT.
Rinse the slices in another Coplin jar with 200 mL of PBS for 5 min.
Counter-stain the slices with 100% hematoxylin for 30 s in a Coplin jar.
Dehydrate the slices with 85%, 95%, and 100% alcohol (200 mL) for 2 min each and treat in xylene (200 mL) for 2 min for 3x. Use Coplin jars to perform each step.
Secure the section on the cover glass with a coverslip using resin. Ensure to avoid the trapping of air bubbles.
6. ELISA
Sample preparation
	
Remove the soft tissues from the femur and the tibia of the mouse. Clean the bones with gauze.
Place the bone samples into a 1 mL microcentrifuge tube and store the sample tubes at -80 °C.
		NOTE: The samples can also be stored in a liquid nitrogen tank for no more than 6 months.
Weigh the bone sample. Dilute with 0.9% PS at a ratio of 1:10. For example, dilute 0.1 g of bone with 1 mL of PS.

Add 3 mm zirconia beads into the tube and grind the samples 3x at 70 Hz for 30 s with 20 s rest in between.
Centrifuge the samples at 4 °C and 12,000 x g for 5 min. Collect the supernatant.
ELISA assay kit
	NOTE: Perform ELISA according to the assay protocol specified by the manufacturer.
	
Add 100 µL of each dilution of standard, blank, and sample into the appropriate wells. Incubate for 90 min at 37 °C.
Decant the liquid from each well and add 100 µL of biotinylated detection antibody working solution. Incubate for 1 h at 37 °C.
Decant the solution, add 350 µL of wash buffer to each well. Soak for 1 min, repeat 3x.
Add 100 µL of HRP conjugate working solution to each well. Incubate for 30 min at 37 °C.
Decant the solution. Repeat the wash process 5x as described in step 6.2.3.
Add 90 µL of the substrate reagent. Incubate for 15 min at 37 °C protected from light.
Add 50 µL of the stop solution.
Use a plate reader to record the absorbance of each well at 450 nm.
Standard curve generation
	
Plot the respective mean absorbance values against the serially diluted protein concentrations.
Join the points to create the best fit curve. Use any appropriate computer application (spreadsheet) to generate the standard curve equation.
Substitute the absorbance value of each sample in the standard curve equation to obtain the concentration of the respective sample.
